validations.reasoning: The extension is a standard implementation of an AI writing assistant. It allows users to 'bring their own key' to interact with LLMs directly from their browser inputs. The static analysis findings for keyboard interception and network calls are verified to be the core functional requirements (triggering the menu and calling the AI APIs). The code uses the Vercel AI SDK, which includes the ai-gateway.vercel.sh endpoint as a standard component for managing LLM requests. There is no evidence of data exfiltration to unauthorized third parties or hidden monetization/tracking logic.

exfiltration_chain.data_collected: User-selected text or input field content.
exfiltration_chain.processing_method: Text is wrapped in a prompt template (e.g., 'Summarize: {text}') and sent to AI providers.
exfiltration_chain.code_evidence: In content.js: d.postMessage({ type: 'generate', prompt: T }) sends text to background.js. In background.js, the Vercel AI SDK processes this request and calls the specified AI provider endpoint.

dual_purpose.stated_purpose: AI-powered text suggestions in any input field or textarea.
dual_purpose.hidden_functionality: None found. The code implementation (UI injection, keyboard shortcuts, and API calling) strictly follows the stated purpose.

credential_theft.capture_mechanism: Users manually enter their own AI API keys into the options or sidepanel pages.
credential_theft.transmission_target: Keys are stored locally via chrome.storage.sync and used to authenticate requests to official AI provider APIs.
credential_theft.code_evidence: In settings-DXyXbL7g.js: const e = await Gi.storage.sync.get(['settings']); and async function Ji(e) { await Gi.storage.sync.set({ settings: e }) }.

pattern_assessment.justification: Used in content.js to detect the 'Ctrl+Y' (default) hotkey to trigger the AI command menu.
Used to send prompts to AI providers and to load the extension's own CSS/assets.
Used by the UI framework (Vue) and the extension logic to detect when new input fields are added to the DOM to attach the AI trigger button.
Used to persist user settings and API keys locally in the browser.

validations.reasoning: The extension uses the Plasmo framework and common libraries like Axios and React. My analysis confirms that the flags generated by static analysis are standard artifacts of these libraries. The network activity is restricted to the target AI domains and a public GitHub repository used for downloading prompt data. There is no evidence of data exfiltration, dual-purpose code for monetization, or credential theft. The code for the BatchScreenshot feature is functionally isolated and uses standard Blob/DOM APIs for UI rendering and image generation.

dual_purpose.stated_purpose: AI prompt assistant to help users ask ChatGPT more efficiently.

pattern_assessment.justification: This flag is triggered by the Axios library included in the bundle. In index.js, it is used for reading the XSRF-TOKEN cookie to prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery, which is standard secure communication behavior.
The extension fetches the 'awesome-chatgpt-prompts' CSV from GitHub. This is consistent with its stated purpose of providing prompt templates.
Used for providing autocomplete features and UI shortcuts within the chat interface.
Triggered by the React framework (react-dom) used to render the extension's UI components over the target web pages.

validations.reasoning: The extension's code is minimal and strictly follows its stated purpose. It performs word and character calculations locally within the content script and updates a UI element in the user's browser. There is no evidence of network activity (fetch/XHR), no data exfiltration, and no suspicious permissions requested in the manifest. The patterns identified by static analysis are standard for UI-modifying extensions.

dual_purpose.stated_purpose: simple word & character counter extension for ChatGPT. it shows how may words are there in the input before sending a prompt

pattern_assessment.justification: The code accesses the DOM to read the value of the '#prompt-textarea' and to create/append a 'counter-div' to display the word count to the user.
The MutationObserver is used to detect when ChatGPT's dynamic UI updates (e.g., when the input area is rendered or changed) to ensure the counter remains visible and accurate.

validations.reasoning: After a thorough review of the source code, the extension appears to be entirely legitimate and safe. The static analysis flagged 'FETCH' and 'NETWORK' patterns, but these are exclusively used to load local dictionary files (vocab.bpe and encoder.json) required for the tokenization algorithm. The extension reads the user's input in the ChatGPT textarea locally, calculates the token count using a standard BPE implementation, and updates the UI. There is no code that transmits user data to an external server, nor is there any evidence of hidden or malicious functionality.

dual_purpose.stated_purpose: A Chrome extension to display the token count for OpenAI chat messages.

pattern_assessment.justification: The fetch calls on lines 11 and 16 are used to load internal resources (vocab.bpe and encoder.json) from the extension's own package to initialize the BPE tokenizer. No external network requests are made.

Used on line 208 to monitor changes in the ChatGPT web application's DOM. This is necessary to re-inject the token counter UI when the page content changes dynamically in the Single Page Application (SPA).

validations.reasoning: The extension's code is minimal, transparent, and strictly follows its stated purpose. It uses the 'webRequest' API to increment a counter whenever the user sends a prompt (via a POST request to the ChatGPT conversation endpoint). The data (timestamps and count) is stored locally using 'chrome.storage.local' and is never transmitted to any external server. There is no evidence of data scraping, credential theft, or dual-purpose functionality.

dual_purpose.stated_purpose: Counts the number of prompts sent to ChatGPT within a 3-hour period.

pattern_assessment.justification: Used to persist the prompt count and the timer values locally within the extension's storage for the UI to display.
Used to detect when a user sends a prompt by monitoring POST requests to the ChatGPT backend API endpoint.
Used to update the countdown timer every second in both the background service worker and the popup UI.
The endpoint https://chatgpt.com/backend-api/conversation is the official ChatGPT API call for sending messages; monitoring it is necessary for the extension's core functionality.
